thread.title: Eugenie Bouchard agrees to second date with Twitter fan
thread.title_full: Eugenie Bouchard agrees to second date with Twitter fan

author: Barney Henderson
title: Eugenie Bouchard agrees to second date with Twitter fan
text:
Eugenie Bouchard agrees to second date with Twitter fan Barney Henderson twitter TWEET More 
A glamorous tennis star and handsome nobody, brought together by a fairytale sporting comeback and a relationship played out to the world on social media. 
While it sounds like it could be the plot of the latest Richard Curtis film, romance appears to be blooming for real for Eugenie Bouchard and an American university student as they plan a second date. The Russian Ministry of Defence has released a video of its latest fighter jet, the Sukhoi-35s, in an effort to drive foreign export sales.Ã‚ More videos 'If the patriots win we go on a date?' 
Tennis star Eugenie Bouchard thought the Atlanta Falcons were clear Super Bowl winners but Twitter user punslayintwoods wasnÃ¢Â€Â™t so sure so he proposed a bet. 
The Canadian tennis star, who models for Sports Illustrated, made a bet with John Goehrke, a 20-year-old student, that the Atlanta Falcons would defeat the New England Patriots in the Super Bowl. 
The Falcons were 21-0 ahead when Bouchard tweeted she was certain Atlanta would win. Related Content 
"If Patriots win [can] we go on a date?" Mr Goehrke tweeted. "Sure," Bouchard fired back. Advertisement 
Sure enough, New England pulled off one of the unlikeliest comebacks in Super Bowl history, winning 34-28 in overtime. Share on Twitter TWEET Link Gotta be in it to win it: John Goehrke sits courtside on his date with Eugenie Bouchard after winning a bet made via Twitter. Photo: Twitter Just met my 'Super Bowl Twitter Date' John ðŸ˜Š On our way to the @BrooklynNets game! @punslayintwoods pic.twitter.com/DHRgY46smd â€” Genie Bouchard (@geniebouchard) February 16, 2017 
The date clearly went well - Bouchard tweeted regular updates to her more than one million followers, including a picture of Mr Goehrke kissing her on the cheek at the end of the evening. 
He followed up with a gift - some earrings from Tiffany's. 
On Friday, she described Mr Goehrke as a "gentleman" and said the date was "awesome!" â€” Genie Bouchard (@geniebouchard) February 16, 2017 
When asked whether there would be a second date, she replied to the reporter: "For sure!" 
"I planned the date. He picked me up at my hotel like a gentleman, then we came over here, he brought me a nice little gift and he enjoyed the game courtside," she said. 
The tennis player, who is currently ranked 44th in the world, admitted that she was "so lucky" Mr Goehrke is "normal". 
Bouchard, who has also reached the semi-finals of the Australian and French Opens, said she had been nervous before the first date. 
"After all the media attention it got, it was something I could, first of all, not back out of. There was no chance," she said. 
"I was worried, however, when I looked at his Twitter profile as soon as I lost the bet and his profile picture was a picture of Tiger Woods. I was like, 'It's one of those Twitter fans. I don't even know what he looks like. What is going to happen?' 
"But it turns out he seems to be a very nice boy." 
The student said it was "amazing" that Bouchard had agreed to the date. 
"The most amazing part is that she agreed to it without knowing who I was," he explained. 
"I thought maybe there was a chance she would respond, but I thought there was no chance she'd actually agree to it." 
It is not the first time celebrities or sports stars have agreed to dates with strangers. Tupac Shakur took a teenager to her prom night after she wrote to him explaining her boyfriend had dumped her. 
In 2011 a US marine made a YouTube video asking Mila Kunis to be his date to the Marine Corps ball - she agreed. 
And a Justin Bieber fan made a website asking him to be her date to her prom night. He replied saying his schedule was too packed to be able to make it - but made up for it by inviting her to be his 'plus one' at the Billboard awards. 
The Telegraph, London
